message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Multiple Mobile Robot Task and Motion Planning: A Survey
Paper Abstract: With recent advances in mobile robotics, autonomous systems, and artificial intelligence, there is a growing expectation that robots are able to solve complex problems. Many of these problems require multiple robots working cooperatively in a multi-robot system. Complex tasks may also include the interconnection of task-level specifications with robot motion-level constraints. Many recent works in the literature use multiple mobile robots to solve these complex tasks by integrating task and motion planning. We survey recent contributions to the field of combined task and motion planning for multiple mobile robots by categorizing works based on their underlying problem representations, and we identify possible directions for future research. We propose a taxonomy for task and motion planning based on system capabilities, applicable to multi-robot and single-robot systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about mobile robots:

## Definition and Overview

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering.

## Key Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Applications

Mobile robots have diverse real-world uses:
- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

## Research and Development

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

Mobile robots have diverse real-world uses:
- Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years.
- Warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

## Research and Development

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

## Motion Planning

Motion planning is a fundamental computational field with numerous applications in robotics and beyond.

### Definition and Core Concept

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration S and a goal configuration G, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.(no content)The robot and obstacle geometry is described in a 2D or 3D workspace, while the motion is represented as a path in (possibly higher-dimensional) configuration space.

### Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video game, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

### Key Algorithms and Approaches

Low-dimensional problems can be solved with grid-based algorithms that overlay a grid on top of configuration space, or geometric algorithms that compute the shape and connectivity of free space. Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.

### Related Concepts

Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment. Additionally, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

## Search Results: Autonomous Robot

I found comprehensive information about autonomous robots. Here's an overview:

### Basic Definition
An autonomous robot is a robot that acts without recourse to human control.

### Examples
Historic examples include space probes, while modern examples include self-driving vacuums and cars.(no content)Industrial robot arms that work on assembly lines inside factories may also be considered autonomous robots.

### Key Capabilities
Autonomous robots must have a range of environmental sensors to perform their task and stay out of trouble.(no content)The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

### Commercial Applications
Several practical applications have emerged:
- **Domestic robots**: A new area showing commercial promise is domestic robots, with a flood of small vacuuming robots beginning with iRobot and Electrolux in 2002.
- **Delivery robots**: A delivery robot is an autonomous robot that provides "last mile" delivery services.(no content)Companies actively delivering include Starship Technologies, which by June 2023 had completed over 5 million commercial autonomous deliveries with their fleet of 2,000 autonomous robots.
- **Security and monitoring**: Amazon launched its Astro for home monitoring, security and eldercare in September 2021.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of task planning:

## General Definition

Task management is the process of overseeing a task through its lifecycle, involving planning, testing, tracking, and reporting.

## Key Components

Task management can help individuals achieve goals or enable groups of individuals to collaborate and share knowledge for the accomplishment of collective goals.(no content)Task planning should facilitate brainstorming, creation, elaboration, clarification, organization, reduction, targeting, and preliminary prioritization.

## Related Areas

**Project Planning:** The project scope is defined and appropriate methods for completing the project are determined, followed by listing durations for various tasks necessary to complete the work and grouping them into a work breakdown structure.

**Time Management:** Time management is the process of planning and exercising conscious control of time spent on specific activities to increase effectiveness, efficiency and productivity.

**Automated Planning:** Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

The search results provide information on various approaches to task planning, from individual task management to complex project planning methodologies and artificial intelligence-based planning systems.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Multi-robot systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-robot_systems"},{"title":"RobotLAB - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RobotLAB"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Asynchronous multi-body framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_multi-body_framework"},{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Middleware for Robotic Applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middleware_for_Robotic_Applications"},{"title":"Morphogenetic robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphogenetic_robotics"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multi-robot systems:

## Overview

Swarm robotics is the study of how to design independent systems of robots without centralized control. The emerging swarming behavior of robotic swarms is created through the interactions between individual robots and the environment.

## Key Characteristics

The design of swarm robotics systems is guided by swarm intelligence principles, which promote fault tolerance, scalability, and flexibility.(no content)Robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings and give feedback to modify the environment, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities (such as wireless transmission systems), do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task.

## Applications

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration with the main goal to control a large number of robots (with limited sensing/processing ability) to accomplish a common task/problem.(no content)Progress has been made in the application of autonomous swarms in the field of manufacturing, known as swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for the production of large structures and components where traditional 3D printing is not able to be utilized due to hardware size constraints.

## Related Research

One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, in which a swarm of up to 20 robots capable of independently physically connecting to each other to form a cooperating system were used to study swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

I've completed a web search for "Artificial intelligence" and found comprehensive information. Here's an overview of what the search returned:

## Definition and Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Types of AI

There are different classifications of AI systems. Weak AI (or narrow AI) can solve one specific problem but lacks general cognitive abilities. In contrast, Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks.

## Applications

AI has been applied across many domains. Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.(no content)Artificial intelligence has been used in applications throughout industry and academia.

## Current Considerations

Recent research shows mixed results on AI's real-world impact. An August 2025 review by MIT found that of surveyed companies, 95% did not report any improvement in revenue from the use of AI.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Multiple Mobile Robot Task and Motion Planning: A Survey". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** `survey` (Literature review of task and motion planning for multiple mobile robots)

**Extracted Entities (7 triples):**

1. **Mobile robot** (concept) - Uses relation - Central subject of the survey
2. **Motion planning** (method) - Uses relation - Core technique for robot movement coordination
3. **Automated planning and scheduling** (method) - Uses relation - Task-level planning integrated with motion constraints
4. **Autonomous robot** (concept) - Uses relation - Independent robot decision-making systems
5. **Swarm robotics** (concept) - Uses relation - Multi-robot coordination approaches
6. **Artificial intelligence** (concept) - Uses relation - Enables complex problem-solving
7. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - Uses relation - Theoretical foundation for cooperative robots

**Validation Result:** ✅ **PASSED** - All triples verified with correct Wikipedia URLs and proper formatting.

The survey paper appropriately lists all key entities as "uses" relations since it reviews existing work in the field, rather than proposing novel methods (which would be "proposes" relations).
